articles.headline: A Tidal Wave of Bankruptcies Is Coming
articles.snippet: Experts foresee so many filings in the coming months that the courts could struggle to salvage the businesses that are worth saving.
articles.abstract: Experts foresee so many filings in the coming months that the courts could struggle to salvage the businesses that are worth saving.
articles.lead_paragraph: Already, companies large and small are succumbing to the effects of the coronavirus. They include household names like Hertz and J. Crew and comparatively anonymous energy companies like Diamond Offshore Drilling and Whiting Petroleum.

articles.headline: Seizing the Presidency to Suit His Own Needs
articles.snippet: In a new book, John R. Bolton portrays Donald Trump as a president who sees his office as an instrument to advance his own personal and political interests over those of the nation.
articles.abstract: In a new book, John R. Bolton portrays Donald Trump as a president who sees his office as an instrument to advance his own personal and political interests over those of the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]

articles.headline: The Biggest Obstacle to China Policy: President Trump
articles.snippet: Overseeing chaotic actions is a president whose goal with Beijing has been to secure a trade deal that would help him get re-elected.
articles.abstract: Overseeing chaotic actions is a president whose goal with Beijing has been to secure a trade deal that would help him get re-elected.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As national security officials and some trade advisers in the Trump administration tried crafting get-tough-on-China policies to address what they viewed as America’s greatest foreign policy challenge, they ran into opposition from an unexpected quarter.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: Police Decisions Are Scrutinized After Rayshard Brooks’s Fatal Encounter
articles.snippet: Experts debate the best way of handling a drunken driver, and whether Mr. Brooks was a threat after twice firing a police Taser.
articles.abstract: Experts debate the best way of handling a drunken driver, and whether Mr. Brooks was a threat after twice firing a police Taser.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Here’s what you need to know about the death of Rayshard Brooks.]
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: In Minneapolis, Looking for Police Recruits Who Can Resist Warrior Culture
articles.snippet: There is a significant difference between the community policing taught in the Minneapolis Police Academy and the ethos of some veteran officers.
articles.abstract: There is a significant difference between the community policing taught in the Minneapolis Police Academy and the ethos of some veteran officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Even as the Minneapolis Police Department reels in the aftermath of its officers’ involvement in the killing of George Floyd, the department has been recruiting a new crop of trainees who will face the same challenge of every rookie: navigating the dramatic difference between what is preached at the academy and what is practiced on the street.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Dan Levin

articles.headline: The Summer Without Rodeos
articles.snippet: Around the country, but mostly in small towns in the West, hundreds of professional rodeos have been canceled.
articles.abstract: Around the country, but mostly in small towns in the West, hundreds of professional rodeos have been canceled.
articles.lead_paragraph: STONYFORD, Calif. — Tucked into the hard wrinkles of Northern California foothills, the one-stop-sign town of Stonyford can feel like the middle of nowhere.

articles.headline: ‘The Last of Us Part II’ Is a Dark Game for a Dark Time
articles.snippet: Set in a violent, tribal, pandemic-ravaged world, the long-awaited Naughty Dog epic will leave you damaged — and awed.
articles.abstract: Set in a violent, tribal, pandemic-ravaged world, the long-awaited Naughty Dog epic will leave you damaged — and awed.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the climax of The Last of Us, a blockbuster 2013 video game that is superficially about a zombie-fungus apocalypse but is really about the lengths a parent will go to protect a child, you are forced to kill a doctor. This doctor is not a threat. He stands there limply, holding a scalpel, so technically he’s not unarmed — but you’ve got a gun and the gameplay has made it clear, after hours of close fighting, that your character could subdue the man peacefully if he wanted.
